product_description: A liquid collagen + hyaluronic acid supplement designed for women 30-55 who want visibly firmer, more hydrated skin without injections. Marine collagen peptides (10g), hyaluronic acid (200mg), vitamin C, biotin. Peach-mango flavor. 30-day supply bottle. Clinically studied ingredients. Results typically visible in 4-8 weeks.
target_market: Women 30-55, US + Canada, health-conscious, interested in anti-aging but skeptical of invasive procedures. Skew: suburban, mid-to-high income, active on Instagram and TikTok.
key_differentiators: Marine collagen (not bovine — cleaner, more sustainable)

competitor_info: Vital Proteins (market leader, $25-45, powder/capsule, celebrity endorsement, 'beauty from within'). NeoCell (budget, $15-20, pills, 'science-backed'). Dose & Co (mid-range, $30, powder, Khloe Kardashian, lifestyle branding). Skinade (premium, $100+, liquid, clinical positioning). Hum Nutrition (DTC, $40, gummies, Instagram-heavy, 'beauty you can taste'). Most competitors lead with 'glowing skin' or 'youthful appearance' — heavy on aspirational imagery, light on mechanism. Common hooks: before/after UGC, 'what I take every morning' routines, dermatologist endorsements. Most ads target Product Aware or Solution Aware women. Very few brands explain WHY collagen works or address skepticism head-on.
landing_page_info: Hero: 'Your skin is losing collagen. This replaces it.' Subhead: '10g marine collagen peptides in a daily drink that actually tastes good.' Social proof bar: '50,000+ bottles sold, 4.7 stars.' Benefits section: firmer skin, stronger nails, better hydration. How it works section: marine collagen → peptide absorption → stimulates natural production. Offer: subscribe & save 20%, 60-day money-back guarantee, free shipping. FAQ covers: how long to see results, is it safe, what about allergies, how is it different from powder.
additional_context: This is the brand's first paid social push. They've been selling organically via Instagram for 6 months with good retention (40% reorder rate). They want to scale to $50k/month ad spend within 3 months. Main concern: not getting flagged for health claims on Meta.
